addressleaf.section:
27 August 1594. From my Lord Th
re
r./.

To S
r
Thomas Bodley in
Holland
touching the Ayd by the Hollanderes in the Queenes Jurney to
Breste
in
bryttany
36 Eli
z

page.lettertext:
fol.224r
1594 27 August To M
r
Bodly
S
r
I have the xxvj
th
day of this August
receaved yo
rs
of the xiiij
th
being the last l
re
co
m
e
to my hands from you: By w
ch
yt appeareth you
make aunswere to myne of the 3
d
whereby I did wryte
unto you as
ticularlie as I mighte of the succors
w
ch
hir
Ma
tie
required of the
States,
and yet me thincketh
you still stande in dowbt what is the determination of
the Quene, so as except they may have more certaintie
of hir Ma
t
proceedings then appeareth yet unto them,
they will but temporize at home: and yet you do write
that
Mons
r
Caron
hath let them to knowe that hir
Ma
tie
hath sent 14 of hir shipps towards
Plimmouth
wherew
th
it seemeth they are not mooved, because
you have not expressed it unto them, by any direction
from hence: and yet yf you doo
use my l
re
of the
third you shall well
ceave what I did signifie to
be hir Ma
t
desyre: so as yf you did take knowledge
thereof, you were sufficientlie in structed what to
demaunde of them; And in that as you say yo
r
suite
hath bin in all yo
r
l
re
s that you might more expreslie
and directlie knowe hir Ma
t
intentions, I do
thinck you ought to be satisfyed w
th
my l
re
of the
vij
th
of July, whereby I did briefly require you to
recommende unto the States, the
ticular demands w
ch
were
dll
by Monsieur Caron, but you sayd it was not
signifyed unto you what those demaunds might importe:
and herein you neede not to be so precize as that you
might not have recomended the same unto them, and
referred you to Carones demaunds, whoe was co
m
a
n
ded
suddenlie to expedite the same, and so he promised to
doo, and hath alwaies aunswered us directely that
the States were well contented therew
th
, and that
he had l
re
s from the
States of Zelande
, promysing
to prepare the sayd shipping, so as I sawe no cause
to wryte any more
ticularly unto you thereof,
untill by my l
re
of the 3 of August, I did expresse
what her Ma
t
meaning was and I thinck it
not amisse for the clearing of yo
r
conceipt, that
you are not advertised as you would be, I would
you should understande that my burden is greate
otherwyse to aunswere farre greater matters, and
that somtimes I am absent, and somtimes syck,
whereas yf I had no other charge then to aunswere
and instruct you as you have nothing else to doo
but in yo
r
owne negociation, you might heare
oftener from me. And whereas in some other
te
of yo
r
l
re
you say thereis varietie betwixt my
wryting and a wryting
dll
unto you by the
fol.224v
States, as from Caron, I am glad that mine doth
expresse xij shippes, where their wryting is for
tenne, soe as by my wrytinge, you had good warrant
to presse them for xij, being more advantage to the
service; and yf you account that a fawlt in my wryting
I am content to aunswere thereto afore any that shall
blame me therfore: and where also you say that my diretion
ys
t
the shipping should come to
Portesmouth,
and Carons
wryting to
Dovar
or the Downes, I am glad also that
my direction hath more advantage for the service, and
yet to reconcile both
distinguenda sunt tempora
, for when
Caron had his order o
r
shipping was then to goe owt
of the Thanni so as then the meeting of both the fleete
was intended to be at Dovar or the Downes: But
afterwarde by the co
m
ing owt of time, and the Quenes
shippes ready to de
te for Portesmouth, It was no
yll direction to appoint the States shippes also to come
thither being more forward for the service, and a better
porte to rest in then Dover. You make also an other
dowbt in that the States stood in dowbt whither her
Ma
t
resolution continewed, because there followed a coun-
termaunde to Caron, w
ch
indeade had not continewaunce
6 howers, for immediately M
r
Caron was niewlie
required to proceede in the first direction notw
th
standing
the countermaund, and so I did cleare that dowbt unto
you in my l
re
, wherein I could not better satisfie you
Furthermore where I did alledge, what the States
had wrytt
e
to M
r
de Caron of the xxix
th
of July,
I will still avowe yt so to be reported by M
r
Caron,
not onely to me but to the Quene, and howsoever the
States beare you in hande w
th
shewing a copie of
their l
re
sent to Caron, I do rayther presume to
credit Caron then their copie of their l
re
, in that
I fynde them unwilling to doo this service, w
ch
is to
so good a purpose, as though her Ma
tie
had not pressed
them thereto, they ought to have offred yt and not
w
th
these trifling aunsweres to delay yt as they have
donne, and so yt appeareth their unwillingnes. And
where they seeme to stande still uppon the dowbt of
the countermaunde I am assured that Caron was ad-
vertised w
th
in 6 howres after the countermaund was
given, that he should proceede as at the first he
was directed, and so he did w
th
in a day or two after
promyse to wryte unto the States, and I do beleve
he did
fourme his promyse: but in this matter I
see plainly the tryfling of the States, and unwillingnes
whatsoever they give owt in words for now (as you
fol.225r
wryte) when you moove them for 30 last
of powder
they make you no good aunsweare thereunto, but
differre it untill all the Deputies of the States be
come togither, so as I see howsoever you have bin
lately instructed or not thoroughly, yet when you
are both instructed, and deale w
th
them in a point
necessary you can get no aunsweare.
You wunder much that yo
r
advertisement of the taking
of
Groeninghen
cam so lately hith
r
, as indeede it did
though you say
M
r
Gilpin
and you dispatched a
post therew
th
, for in trueth the newes thereof,
were
ticularly certifyed to my
L. of Essex
, and
c
o
mon in London before we could heare a worde thereof
from you: and therefore yo
r
post ought to make
better aunswere thereunto for his negligence: And
yf it be as you say, that yo
r
post brought yo
r
l
re
s
to my L. of Essex then he dealt lyke A varlet
w
th
me to keepe my l
re
s so long after my L. had
received his. You require to me to
don you
a litle that you speake to me w
th
some plainnes,
when you feele yo
r
selfe encombred w
th
the burden
of yo
r
service for want of dew information: and
so do I require you to be are w
th
me in plaine
wryting that do fynde you more scrupulous then
neede is. And so wishing you that you would
requyre some resolute resolution of the States of
t
they are disposed to doo w
th
owt using cavillations, as
yt seemeth they do at this time, and so they do in
all negociations you have w
th
them giving g
n
ll good
words, and yet in
ticularity making alwayes
delayes. I thinck my next dispatch unto
you shalbe to send you her Ma
t
l
re
according to
yo
r
desyre to lycense yo
r
comming fr
o
thence w
ch
stayeth a few dayes untill a c
o
sultation may be had,
for sending of an expresse message to the
Archduke Ernestus
from hence, of w
ch
matter
you shall have information to deliver the same to
the States.
From Grenwych the 27 of
August.
1594
.
Yo
r
loving friend William Burghley
